heading: 1.1 Introduction: how we know what we know
text:
soiled shirt placed opening vessel containing grains wheat, reaction leaven shirt fumes wheat , approximately twenty-one days, transform wheat mice.called 'spontaneous generation' ('abiogenesis').
theory clearly incorrect, idea emerge?
disproven?
observation research.Spontaneous generation consistent observations: following recipe produce mice.
However, hypothesis ('possible explanation') spontaneous generation rejected later evidence, better-designed research studies, contradicted hypothesis.
new hypothesis proposed explain appearance mice, tested evidence, .
Briefly, evidence-based, scientific process.recent example, dangers smoking still debated 1990s:... causal role smoking [] proved beyond reasonable doubt.--- Eysenck (1991), p. 429All scientific knowledge emerges similar way: observations lead questions hypotheses, tested evidence.
evidence contradicts hypothesis, hypothesis rejected.
evidence consistent hypothesis, hypothesis temporarily accepted (contradictory evidence emerges, ever).Hypotheses contradicted large amounts evidence, long time, sometimes called laws theories ('Law conservation energy').
Theories laws can disproven contradictory evidence emerges.
Knowledge scientific disciplines accumulated using similar evidence-based process.

heading: 1.2 Evidence-based research
text:
Every discipline changes, develops, improves, adapts---usually research.
discipline ten years ago; change next ten years.
Scientists, engineers health practitioners need know understand adapt change.Remaining current discipline requires understanding research, even researching .
still need know language, tools, concepts ideas research, need able critique research.
Research foundation science.Science seeks evidence-based answers: reaching conclusions based evidence, rather hunches, feelings, intuition, hopes, tradition.
evidence comes analysing data.Definition 1.1  (Data) 
Data refers information (observations measurements), numbers, labels, recordings, videos, text, etc.dataset refers organised structured collection data.Research involves asking research questions, designing studies collect data, analysing data, accurately reporting results.
book covers components.

heading: 1.3 Quantitative, qualitative, and mixed-methods research
text:
Research can broadly classified qualitative quantitative.
different yet complementary approaches answering research questions (Table 1.1).
methods advantages disadvantages, can used together (called mixed-methods research).
decision use qualitative, quantitative mixed-methods approaches depends purpose research.
TABLE 1.1: Concisely comparing qualitative quantitative research.
Briefly, qualitative research leads deeper understanding, usually specific group.
Meanings, motivations, opinions themes often emerge qualitative research.
contrast, quantitative research summarises analyses data usually large groups, using numerical methods, averages percentages.
quantitative research, typically information large group interest (population) found subset population (sample).Definition 1.2  (Quantitative research) Quantitative research summarises analyses data using numerical methods, averages, proportions percentages.book quantitative research.Example 1.1  (Types research) Oliveira et al. (2020) used mixed-methods research study adoption electric taxis Nottingham (UK).quantitative component study, taxis tracked \(32\,000\,\text{km}\) \(9\,764\,\text{h}\).
researchers determined taxis often stopped (potential charging locations).
Trent Street taxi rank (near main train station) -used stop average wait time \(20\,\text{mins}\);
Milton St (\(17\,\text{mins}\)) Wheeler gate (\(10\,\text{mins}\)) also recorded high average stop-times.
Numerical information speeds also obtained.qualitative component study, nine taxis drivers participated interviews focus groups.
allowed researchers (p. 6)...explore themes motivations way possible initial quantitative analysis.Participants' responses classified barriers (safety; costs; speeds) facilitators (opportunities charge regularly; convenient locations) proposed charging locations.Example 1.2  (Quantitative research) 1988/1989, unusually high number Legionella longbeachae infections observed South Australians.
researchers (O’Connor et al. 2007) wanted identify source prevent infections.researchers noticed many infected gardeners recently handled potting mix, hypothesised infection associated using potting mix.
designed study test hypothesis, collected data \(100\) people (\(25\) infection, \(75\) people similar age sex without infection).researchers classified summarised data, analysed data reach evidence-based conclusion: potting mix partially, solely, responsible infections.
researchers communicated recommendations 
reduce risks people contracting infection future.book explains six steps research.

heading: 1.4 The steps in research
text:
research process (qualitative quantitative research) ideally follows process summarised Fig. 1.1, always possible practical.
process always linear: researchers may jump step step necessary, research often leads new research questions (RQs) process restarts.
step important.
FIGURE 1.1: six basic steps research.
Asking RQ (Chap. 2).
Research begins research question answer.Designing study (Chaps. 3  8).
Evidence-based research uses data answer RQ.
study designed obtain data: determining study; finding study; deciding information obtain; ensuring data obtained ethically.Collecting data (Chap. 9).
data collection process must ethical, reproducible clearly documented.Classifying summarising data (Chaps. 10  17).
analysis, data must classified summarised inform analysis.
(computer useful.)Analysing data (Chaps. 18  34).
Analysis refers using data find answer research question.
(computer useful.)Reporting results (Chaps. 35  36).
Communicating results appropriately, accurately ethically important, including identifying limitations research.

heading: 1.5 Using computers in research
text:
Statistical software (Python, jamovi, R, SAS, SPSS, Stata, etc.) useful summarising analysing data.
Statistical software:designed working large datasets.encourages reproducible research (Sect. 5.3).allows high-precision formatting graphics.powerful; programming skills, almost anything possible.specifically designed analysing working data.book sometimes shows output jamovi (jamovi Project 2022), using jamovi essential understanding book.Using spreadsheets storing analysing data requires care.
Expensive dangerous errors made due using spreadsheets (AlTarawneh Thorne 2016).
challenges using spreadsheets include :spreadsheets may change data (e.g., reformatting entries dates) appropriate (Ziemann, Eren, El-Osta 2016).spreadsheets may include formulas errors difficult locate hence fix (Panko 2015; London Slagter 2021).spreadsheets leave record data analysed prepared.
Keeping record analysis, preparation variables, operations data good scientific practice (reproducible research; see Sect. 5.3) (Simons Holmes 2019).spreadsheets often produce poor graphs (Su 2008).

Problems spreadsheets, software, often due human error, spreadsheets make errors hard find hence hard fix.
Spreadsheets useful data collection basic data manipulation, designed scientific analysis.
careful using spreadsheets research analysis.

heading: 2.1 Introduction
text:
research question (RQ) directs components research.
Since quantitative research summarises analyses data using numerical methods (like averages percentages), RQ must written carefully can answered effectively.
Four different types RQs studied:descriptive RQs (Sect. 2.2).relational RQs (Sect. 2.3).repeated-measures RQs (Sect. 2.4).correlational RQs (Sect. 2.6).Since RQ directs components research, writing RQs first step research study.
Specifically, RQs asked data collected.RQs written data collected.

heading: 2.2 Descriptive RQs
text:
RQs identify large group interest studied (called population), study something population (called outcome).population broad group interest; example:German males  \(18\)  \(35\) years age.bamboo flooring materials manufactured China.elderly females glaucoma Canada.Pinguicula grandiflora growing Europe.Definition 2.1  (Population) 
population group individuals total set observations interest made, results generalise.Populations comprise many individuals (cases).
individuals people, individuals may also called subjects.words population, individuals cases just refer people, though may commonly used way general conversation.Data rarely taken individuals population: individuals rarely accessible practice.
example, testing new drug possibly study people might use drug (may even born yet).
contrast, sample subset population data obtained (Chap. 6).
Countless samples possible given population, one studied.Definition 2.2  (Sample) 
sample subset individuals population.
data collected sample.population RQ just studied; whole group results generalise.Example 2.1  (Samples) study American college women (Woolf et al. 2009) compared iron status highly-active sedentary women.study compared \(28\) active  \(28\) sedentary American college women, data collected.
population active sedentary American college women.
group \(56\) subjects sample.Descriptive RQs study something identified population, called outcome.
RQ concerns large group (population), outcome numerically describes group individuals (single individuals).
outcome , example, average proportion summarising group individuals.Definition 2.3  (Outcome) 
outcome RQ result, output, consequence effect interest study, numerically summarised group individuals.outcome interest population may (example) theaverage amount wear  \(1\,000\,\text{h}\) use.proportion people whose pupils dilate.average weight loss three weeks diet.percentage seedlings die.
outcome RQ summarises population; describe individuals population.Descriptive RQs can now introduced.Definition 2.4  (Descriptive RQ) Descriptive RQs population outcome.RQs ask value population quantity (: average internal body temperature?); called estimation RQs.
RQs require making decision population (: average internal body temperature females males?); called decision-making RQs.
Descriptive RQs one forms, depending information sought (Sect. 2.8):estimation RQs: Among {population}, {outcome}?decision-making RQs: Among {population}, {outcome} equal {given value}?templates 'recipes', guidelines.Answering estimation descriptive RQs studied Chaps. 22  23.
Answering decision-making descriptive RQs studied Chaps. 26  27.Example 2.2  (Descriptive RQ) Mackowiak, Wasserman, Levine (1992) studied men women aged \(18\)  \(40\); population.
outcome interest population average body temperature.
sample comprised \(148\) 'healthy men women' aged \(18\)  \(40\).
One descriptive RQ :average body temperature?estimation RQ.
also studied decision-making descriptive RQ ( \(98.6\)( \(37.0\)oC) commonly-accepted value internal body temperature):average body temperature really \(98.6\)(\(37.0\)oC)?

heading: 2.3 Relational RQs
text:
Studying relationships usually interesting simply describing population.
Relational RQs compare outcome groups different individuals population, compare two different sub-populations.
comparisons called -individuals comparisons, compare outcome (among) groups different individuals.
Examples include:comparing average amount wear floorboards two different groups: standard wooden floorboards, bamboo floorboards.comparing average heart rate across three groups people: receiving drug, receiving weekly dose, receiving daily dose drug.Definition 2.5  (Comparison (individuals)) -individuals comparison RQ identifies small number groups different individuals outcome compared.Example 2.3  (-individuals comparison) J. L. Williams et al. (2022) compared average weight female male Leadbeater's possums.
'Sex possum' -individuals comparison; average weight outcome.Relational RQs can now introduced.Definition 2.6  (Relational RQ) Relational RQs population, outcome, -individuals comparison.Relational RQs one forms, depending information sought:estimation RQ: Among {population}, difference {outcome} {groups compared}?decision-making RQ: Among {population}, {outcome} {groups compared}?Example 2.4  (Relational RQ) Consider RQ (based Estévez-Báez et al. (2019)):Among Cubans  \(13\)  \(20\) years age, average heart rate females males?population 'Cubans \(13\)  \(20\) years age', outcome 'average heart rate', -individuals comparison two separate groups: 'females males'.
relational RQ.decision-making RQ, since asks average heart rate females males.
estimation-type relational RQ ask size difference average heart rate females males.

heading: 2.4 Repeated-measures RQs
text:
Rather comparing outcome groups different individuals, repeated-measures RQs compare outcome multiple times within individuals.comparisons called within-individuals comparisons, compare outcome within individuals, across groups different individuals.
multiple measurements may different points time (e.g., height trees one, two five years planting), time points.Examples include:comparing average strength hind legs horses forelegs horses.comparing average thickness cornea left eyes right eyes individuals.comparing average amount wear many individual floorboards one, five ten years use.Definition 2.7  (Within-individuals comparison) within-individuals comparison RQ identifies small number different, distinct situations outcome compared individual.Example 2.5  (- within-individual comparisons) Consider comparing strength dominant non-dominant legs professional football players.-individuals comparison compare average strengths dominant non-dominant legs different groups footballers: one group dominant-leg strength measured, non-dominant-leg strength measured.
-individuals comparison.contrast, strengths dominant non-dominant legs recorded individuals.

chapter: C Symbols, formulas, statistics and parameters
heading: C.2 Confidence intervals
text:
statistics whose sampling distribution approximate normal distribution, confidence intervals (CIs) form
\[
    \text{statistic} \pm \big( \text{multiplier} \times \text{s.e.}(\text{statistic})\big).
\]Notes:multiplier approximately \(2\) create approximate \(95\)% CI (based \(68\)--\(95\)--\(99.7\) rule).quantity '\(\text{multiplier} \times \text{s.e.}(\text{statistic})\)' called margin error.Software uses exact multipliers form exact confidence intervals.sampling distribution statistic approximate normal distribution (e.g., ORs correlation coefficients), formula apply CIs taken directly software output available.

chapter: C Symbols, formulas, statistics and parameters
heading: C.3 Hypothesis testing
text:
statistics whose sampling distribution approximate normal distribution, test statistic form:
\[
  \text{test statistic} = \frac{\text{statistic} - \text{parameter}}{\text{s.e.}(\text{statistic})},
\]
\(\text{s.e.}(\text{statistic})\) standard error statistic.
test-statistic \(t\)-score hypothesis tests book sampling distribution described normal distribution, \(z\)-score hypothesis test involving one two proportions.Notes:test-statistic \(z\)-score, \(P\)-value can found using tables
(Appendix B.1),
approximated using \(68\)--\(95\)--\(99.7\) rule.test-statistic \(t\)-score, \(P\)-value can approximated using tables
(Appendix B.1),

Also called empirical rule.

sources used writing research acknowledged avoid plagiarism.
